classifiedComments.comment:
Hello , I hope you're doing well! Im going through NextJs and trying to learn and explore.I have a question related to optimizing server-side and client-side rendering and would appreciate your insights.

How can I ensure that only the first user request is server-side rendered (SSR), and subsequent route transitions are rendered client-side without triggering the SSR function again? My goal is to minimize requests to the server while maintaining a seamless experience.

Thank you for your time, and I’d be grateful for any advice or guidance you can share!

commentData.textDisplay:
Hello , I hope you're doing well! Im going through NextJs and trying to learn and explore.I have a question related to optimizing server-side and client-side rendering and would appreciate your insights.

How can I ensure that only the first user request is server-side rendered (SSR), and subsequent route transitions are rendered client-side without triggering the SSR function again? My goal is to minimize requests to the server while maintaining a seamless experience.

Thank you for your time, and I’d be grateful for any advice or guidance you can share!
commentData.textOriginal:
Hello , I hope you're doing well! Im going through NextJs and trying to learn and explore.I have a question related to optimizing server-side and client-side rendering and would appreciate your insights.

How can I ensure that only the first user request is server-side rendered (SSR), and subsequent route transitions are rendered client-side without triggering the SSR function again? My goal is to minimize requests to the server while maintaining a seamless experience.

Thank you for your time, and I’d be grateful for any advice or guidance you can share!

classifiedComments.comment:
Excellent tutorial, thank you!  I appreciate you get straight to the point.  I often had things occurring to me, and you would immediately address them - so fab job with anticipating questions!

I would just say that the Authentication section is a little too specific, as, although cool, it depends on a third party.  An example based on AWS Cognito (something more mainstream) would be good.

Thanks again.

commentData.textDisplay:

classifiedComments.comment: Thank you for putting together this crash course, it is well explained and I learned a lot. One question though; regarding the Bearer Token in the page.tsx within the mock-users folder @45:33. You mentioned that it is safer because it would be ran in the server-side. However, would still be a vulnerability is I push the key (hard-coded) to repository or the like?

classifiedComments.comment:
I would like to point out that at 16:49 you used 'await' but it shows a squiggle because you didnt mention the type as a promise.

This may become an issue when using 'npm run build' because when trying to compile it to js, params will be missing the properties of 'Promise'.

And yes for anyone wondering, these issues aren't visible when we are in development mode i.e. 'npm run dev'

commentData.textDisplay:
I would like to point out that at 16:49 you used 'await' but it shows a squiggle because you didnt mention the type as a promise.

This may become an issue when using 'npm run build' because when trying to compile it to js, params will be missing the properties of 'Promise'.

And yes for anyone wondering, these issues aren't visible when we are in development mode i.e. 'npm run dev'
commentData.textOriginal:
I would like to point out that at 16:49 you used 'await' but it shows a squiggle because you didnt mention the type as a promise.

This may become an issue when using 'npm run build' because when trying to compile it to js, params will be missing the properties of 'Promise'.

And yes for anyone wondering, these issues aren't visible when we are in development mode i.e. 'npm run dev'
